title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 23 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Chronicles chapter 23 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 23 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Chronicles Chapter 23.

questions.question: Who did Jehoiada take into covenant with him in the seventh year?
options: The captains of hundreds
The prophets of Judah
The priests of Israel
The elders of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: The captains of hundreds
questions.explanation: Jehoiada took the captains of hundreds into covenant with him in the seventh year (2 Chronicles 23:1).

questions.question: From where did the Levites and the chief of the fathers of Israel gather to come to Jerusalem?
options: From all the cities of Judah
From the deserts of Moab
From the land of Egypt
From the city of Samaria
questions.correctAnswer: From all the cities of Judah
questions.explanation: They gathered the Levites out of all the cities of Judah and the chief of the fathers of Israel, and they came to Jerusalem (2 Chronicles 23:2).

questions.question: What did all the congregation do with the king in the house of God?
options: Made a covenant with the king
Rebuked the king
Anointed the king with oil
Sang a new song
questions.correctAnswer: Made a covenant with the king
questions.explanation: All the congregation made a covenant with the king in the house of God (2 Chronicles 23:3).

questions.question: According to Jehoiada's instructions, where should a third part of the priests and Levites be stationed on the sabbath?
options: Porters of the doors
At the king's house
At the gate of the foundation
In the fields outside Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Porters of the doors
questions.explanation: Jehoiada said a third part of the priests and Levites shall be porters of the doors (2 Chronicles 23:4).

questions.question: True or False: Jehoiada commanded that all the people should go inside the house of the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Only the priests and those who minister of the Levites shall go in; all other people should keep watch (2 Chronicles 23:6).

questions.question: What were the Levites instructed to do around the king?
options: Compass the king round about, every man with his weapons in his hand
Sing praises to the king
Bring the king gifts
Stand silently at a distance
questions.correctAnswer: Compass the king round about, every man with his weapons in his hand
questions.explanation: The Levites were to compass the king round about with weapons in their hands (2 Chronicles 23:7).

questions.question: What did Jehoiada give to the captains of hundreds from the house of God?
options: Spears, bucklers, and shields that had been king David's
Scrolls of the law
Golden crowns
Horses and chariots
questions.correctAnswer: Spears, bucklers, and shields that had been king David's
questions.explanation: Jehoiada delivered to the captains of hundreds spears, bucklers, and shields that had been king David's (2 Chronicles 23:9).

questions.question: Where were the armed men set by Jehoiada during the coronation of the king's son?
options: From the right side of the temple to the left side, along by the altar and the temple
On the city walls
In the king's palace
By the gates of the city
questions.correctAnswer: From the right side of the temple to the left side, along by the altar and the temple
questions.explanation: Jehoiada set all the armed men from the right side of the temple to the left side by the altar and temple (2 Chronicles 23:10).

questions.question: What was done to the king's son before making him king?
options: They put a crown on him and anointed him
They gave him a sword
They made him sit on the throne immediately
They gave him a golden scepter
questions.correctAnswer: They put a crown on him and anointed him
questions.explanation: They brought out the king's son, put upon him the crown, gave him the testimony, and Jehoiada and his sons anointed him (2 Chronicles 23:11).

questions.question: True or False: Athaliah came to the house of the LORD when she heard the noise of the people praising the king.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Athaliah came to the people in the house of the LORD upon hearing the noise of the people running and praising the king (2 Chronicles 23:12).

questions.question: What did Athaliah do when she saw the king standing at his pillar?
options: Rent her clothes and cried 'Treason, Treason'
Fell down and worshiped
Called for the priests
Sang a lament
questions.correctAnswer: Rent her clothes and cried 'Treason, Treason'
questions.explanation: Athaliah rent her clothes and declared 'Treason, Treason' when she saw the king (2 Chronicles 23:13).

questions.question: Where was Athaliah slain as commanded by Jehoiada?
options: At the entering of the horse gate by the king's house
In the house of the LORD
On the temple mount
At the city gate
questions.correctAnswer: At the entering of the horse gate by the king's house
questions.explanation: Athaliah was slain at the entering of the horse gate by the king's house (2 Chronicles 23:15).

questions.question: What did the people do to the house of Baal after making a covenant with the king and Jehoiada?
options: Broke it down and slew Mattan the priest of Baal
Cleaned and purified it
Offered sacrifices there
Left it alone
questions.correctAnswer: Broke it down and slew Mattan the priest of Baal
questions.explanation: All the people went to the house of Baal, broke it down, and slew Mattan the priest of Baal before the altars (2 Chronicles 23:17).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jehoiada appointed the offices of the house of the LORD by the hand of the priests the Levites, whom David had distributed in the house of the LORD, to offer the burnt offerings of the LORD, as it is written in the law of Moses, with ______ and with singing.
options: rejoicing
weeping
silence
mourning
questions.correctAnswer: rejoicing
questions.explanation: Jehoiada appointed the Levites to offer burnt offerings with rejoicing and singing as ordained by David (2 Chronicles 23:18).

questions.question: True or False: Jehoiada allowed unclean persons to enter the house of the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jehoiada set the porters at the gates so that none which was unclean should enter in (2 Chronicles 23:19).

medium.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 23 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Chronicles Chapter 23 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 23 teach us about the importance of faithful leadership in times of spiritual crisis?
options: Jehoiada took decisive action to restore the rightful king and purge idolatry
Athaliah peacefully supported the king’s reign
The people remained passive and did not intervene
The Levites abandoned their duties
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoiada took decisive action to restore the rightful king and purge idolatry
questions.explanation: Jehoiada strengthened himself, gathered leaders and Levites, and restored the king, while removing Athaliah and destroying Baal’s temple (2 Chronicles 23:1-3, 14-17). This shows the importance of faithful leadership during spiritual crises.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God’s plan during difficult times. Based on 2 Chronicles 23, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God’s promises will be fulfilled despite opposition, as seen when the king’s son was restored
God abandons His people in times of trouble
Trust is unimportant compared to human plans
Faith requires no action or obedience
questions.correctAnswer: God’s promises will be fulfilled despite opposition, as seen when the king’s son was restored
questions.explanation: The people made a covenant affirming that the king’s son shall reign as the LORD promised (2 Chronicles 23:3). Despite Athaliah’s opposition, God's promise was fulfilled through Jehoiada’s faithful actions (verses 11-15).

questions.question: What does the organization of the Levites and priests around the temple teach us about spiritual discipline and order in church life?
options: A third guarded the doors, a third the king’s house, a third the gate, maintaining holiness
Everyone entered the temple freely without roles
Only priests were allowed outside the temple
The Levites were not involved in temple duties
questions.correctAnswer: A third guarded the doors, a third the king’s house, a third the gate, maintaining holiness
questions.explanation: Jehoiada instructed the Levites to guard the temple in organized divisions to maintain holiness and order (2 Chronicles 23:4-6). This exemplifies disciplined service and respect for God’s house.

questions.question: How does the chapter illustrate the biblical virtue of courage in the face of opposition?
options: Jehoiada and the Levites stood guard with weapons to protect the king and enforce God’s will
The people fled from confrontation
Athaliah’s forces overpowered the Levites
No one acted out of fear
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoiada and the Levites stood guard with weapons to protect the king and enforce God’s will
questions.explanation: The Levites held weapons to protect the king and enforce God’s law, showing courage and faithfulness despite danger (2 Chronicles 23:7, 10).

questions.question: In what way does 2 Chronicles 23 teach about the importance of accountability and covenant commitment in the community of faith?
options: All the congregation made a covenant with the king and God’s people, committing themselves
Only the priests made promises
The people acted without any formal agreement
The covenant was made secretly among few leaders
questions.correctAnswer: All the congregation made a covenant with the king and God’s people, committing themselves
questions.explanation: The people gathered and made a covenant with the king in God’s house, signifying public commitment and accountability (2 Chronicles 23:3, 16).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with temptation to compromise their faith in difficult situations. What example from 2 Chronicles 23 encourages them to persevere?
options: Jehoiada maintained the priestly courses and faithful service without compromise
The Levites gave up their duties
Athaliah convinced everyone to follow her
The people ignored God’s commands
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoiada maintained the priestly courses and faithful service without compromise
questions.explanation: Jehoiada did not dismiss the priestly courses or compromise but ensured faithful service to God (2 Chronicles 23:8, 18). This teaches perseverance and obedience in trials.

questions.question: What biblical principle about stewardship and honoring God’s heritage is taught in 2 Chronicles 23?
options: Jehoiada gave the captains weapons that belonged to King David, kept in the house of God
Weapons were taken from the people without care
No regard was given to historic items
The king’s weapons were sold
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoiada gave the captains weapons that belonged to King David, kept in the house of God
questions.explanation: Jehoiada entrusted the captains with David’s weapons preserved in God’s house, showing respect and wise stewardship of sacred heritage (2 Chronicles 23:9).

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Chronicles 23, only the priests and Levites who minister were allowed to enter the house of the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 6 states that none but the priests and ministering Levites were permitted to enter the house of the LORD, emphasizing holiness and separation.

questions.question: How does the chapter demonstrate the importance of worship and rejoicing in spiritual renewal?
options: The people rejoiced with trumpets, singers, and instruments when the king was restored
The people were silent and mourned
Worship was forbidden during the restoration
Only the priests worshiped
questions.correctAnswer: The people rejoiced with trumpets, singers, and instruments when the king was restored
questions.explanation: The restoration of the king was celebrated with joyful praise and music, showing worship as a vital part of spiritual renewal (2 Chronicles 23:13).

questions.question: A church leader wants to teach about purity and holiness in the church. What instruction from 2 Chronicles 23 would you share?
options: Porters were set at the gates to prevent anyone unclean from entering the house of the LORD
Everyone could enter regardless of purity
Only the king controlled access to the temple
The gates were left open at all times
questions.correctAnswer: Porters were set at the gates to prevent anyone unclean from entering the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: Jehoiada set porters at the gates to guard the holiness of the temple by not allowing the unclean to enter (2 Chronicles 23:19).

questions.question: True or False: The people of Judah went to the house of Baal and destroyed it after the king was restored.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 17 records that the people broke down the house of Baal, destroyed altars and images, and killed the priest of Baal, showing decisive rejection of idolatry.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 23 illustrate the importance of community involvement in supporting godly leadership?
options: All the people and leaders participated in bringing down the king and setting him on the throne
Only priests were involved in leadership
The people stayed isolated from the king’s affairs
The Levites opposed the king
questions.correctAnswer: All the people and leaders participated in bringing down the king and setting him on the throne
questions.explanation: Jehoiada involved captains, nobles, governors, and all the people to bring the king down from the temple and establish him on the throne (2 Chronicles 23:20), showing community support for godly leadership.

questions.question: What does the anointing of the king by Jehoiada and his sons teach about spiritual authority and blessing?
options: Anointing symbolizes God’s blessing and authority conferred by priestly leadership
Anointing was a political ceremony without spiritual meaning
The king was crowned without any religious ceremony
The people rejected the anointing
questions.correctAnswer: Anointing symbolizes God’s blessing and authority conferred by priestly leadership
questions.explanation: Jehoiada and his sons anointed the king, signifying God’s chosen authority and blessing (2 Chronicles 23:11).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jehoiada made a covenant between himself, the people, and the king, that they should be the ______ people.
options: LORD'S
king's
Levites'
priests'
questions.correctAnswer: LORD'S
questions.explanation: Jehoiada made a covenant that they should be the LORD’S people, signifying commitment to God’s authority and guidance (2 Chronicles 23:16).

questions.question: How does the handling of Athaliah’s opposition demonstrate the biblical principle of justice balanced with reverence for God’s house?
options: She was removed and executed outside the house of the LORD, respecting its sanctity
She was executed inside the temple
She was forgiven without consequences
She remained in power
questions.correctAnswer: She was removed and executed outside the house of the LORD, respecting its sanctity
questions.explanation: Jehoiada ordered that Athaliah not be slain in the LORD’s house but outside by the king’s house (2 Chronicles 23:14-15), showing respect for holiness alongside justice.

hard.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 23 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Chronicles Chapter 23.

questions.question: Who were the captains of hundreds that Jehoiada took into covenant with him in the seventh year?
options: Azariah son of Jeroham, Ishmael son of Jehohanan, Azariah son of Obed, Maaseiah son of Adaiah, Elishaphat son of Zichri
Joab son of Zeruiah, Abner son of Ner, Amasa son of Jether, Benaiah son of Jehoiada
Nathan son of David, Zadok son of Ahitub, Abiathar son of Ahimelech, Eleazar son of Aaron
Azariah son of Zadok, Jehohanan son of Azariah, Obed son of Maaseiah, Adaiah son of Elishaphat
questions.correctAnswer: Azariah son of Jeroham, Ishmael son of Jehohanan, Azariah son of Obed, Maaseiah son of Adaiah, Elishaphat son of Zichri
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:1 explicitly lists these five captains as those Jehoiada took into covenant with him.

questions.question: What was the purpose of gathering the Levites and the chief fathers of Israel to Jerusalem according to 2 Chronicles 23?
options: To make a covenant with the king in the house of God
To prepare for a war against the Assyrians
To rebuild the temple and restore the altar
To celebrate the Feast of Tabernacles
questions.correctAnswer: To make a covenant with the king in the house of God
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states that all the congregation made a covenant with the king in the house of God.

questions.question: What proportion of priests and Levites was assigned as porters of the doors on the Sabbath?
options: A third part
Half
Two-thirds
All of them
questions.correctAnswer: A third part
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:4 specifies that a third part of the priests and Levites entering on the Sabbath were to be porters of the doors.

questions.question: Why were only priests and those ministering of the Levites allowed to enter the house of the LORD?
options: Because they are holy
Because they were the only ones trained
Because the people were unclean
Because the house was under repair
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are holy
questions.explanation: Verse 6 explains that only priests and ministering Levites could enter because they are holy, while the people kept watch.

questions.question: What weapons did Jehoiada the priest give to the captains of hundreds, and where were they kept?
options: Spears, bucklers, and shields; kept in the house of God and had belonged to King David
Swords and bows; kept in the armory of the king's palace
Slings and stones; kept in the city gates
Spears and helmets; kept in the treasury
questions.correctAnswer: Spears, bucklers, and shields; kept in the house of God and had belonged to King David
questions.explanation: Verse 9 states Jehoiada delivered spears, bucklers, and shields that had been King David's and were in the house of God.

questions.question: How does the crowning of the king's son in 2 Chronicles 23:11 serve as a typological fulfillment of God's promise to David?
options: It fulfills the promise that a son of David would reign on the throne
It symbolizes the end of the Davidic line
It represents the people's rejection of God's covenant
It marks the beginning of foreign domination
questions.correctAnswer: It fulfills the promise that a son of David would reign on the throne
questions.explanation: Verse 3 and 11 together emphasize that the king's son reigning is according to the LORD's promise concerning David's descendants.

questions.question: What was Athaliah's reaction upon hearing the noise of the people praising the king, and what does this reveal about her role?
options: She rent her clothes and cried 'Treason, Treason,' revealing her opposition to the legitimate king
She joined the celebration, showing her acceptance of the new king
She fled the city in fear, indicating her guilt
She prayed in the temple, seeking forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: She rent her clothes and cried 'Treason, Treason,' revealing her opposition to the legitimate king
questions.explanation: Verse 13 shows Athaliah's reaction as one of outrage and accusation of treason, indicating her resistance to Jehoiada's plan and the new king.

questions.question: What order did Jehoiada give concerning Athaliah's removal, and what does this indicate about respect for the sanctuary?
options: She was to be taken out of the temple ranges and slain outside, as she was not to be killed in the house of the LORD
She was to be executed immediately within the temple precincts
She was to be exiled to a foreign land
She was to be imprisoned inside the temple
questions.correctAnswer: She was to be taken out of the temple ranges and slain outside, as she was not to be killed in the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 14 shows Jehoiada commanded that Athaliah not be slain in the LORD's house, respecting the sanctity of the temple.

questions.question: After the covenant between Jehoiada, the people, and the king, what actions did the people take against Baal worship?
options: They broke down Baal's house, destroyed his altars and images, and killed Mattan the priest of Baal
They built new altars to Baal alongside the temple
They ignored Baal worship and focused on the LORD's temple
They sent the priests of Baal into exile
questions.correctAnswer: They broke down Baal's house, destroyed his altars and images, and killed Mattan the priest of Baal
questions.explanation: Verse 17 describes how the people demolished Baal's house and killed the priest as a rejection of idolatry after the covenant.

questions.question: How did Jehoiada organize the temple service after the coup against Athaliah, and what does this suggest about continuity with Davidic reforms?
options: He appointed priests and Levites as David had done, to offer burnt offerings with rejoicing and singing
He abolished the temple service and centralized worship in the palace
He introduced foreign worship practices in the temple
He left the temple service unorganized and chaotic
questions.correctAnswer: He appointed priests and Levites as David had done, to offer burnt offerings with rejoicing and singing
questions.explanation: Verse 18 shows Jehoiada restored the temple order according to David's prior arrangement, emphasizing liturgical continuity.

questions.question: Why did Jehoiada set porters at the gates of the house of the LORD, and what does this reveal about the community's purity concerns?
options: To prevent anyone unclean from entering, reflecting the importance of ritual purity
To collect taxes from worshippers
To guard against foreign invaders
To control access for royal officials only
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent anyone unclean from entering, reflecting the importance of ritual purity
questions.explanation: Verse 19 indicates porters guarded the gates to keep out those who were ritually unclean, highlighting purity laws.

questions.question: What is the significance of the people bringing down the king from the house of the LORD through the high gate into the king's house to be set on the throne?
options: It symbolizes divine approval and the rightful installation of the king in his royal authority
It was a secretive act to avoid public attention
It was a sign of the king's submission to the priests
It indicated the king was being exiled from the temple
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes divine approval and the rightful installation of the king in his royal authority
questions.explanation: Verse 20 portrays the transition of the king from sacred space to royal throne, symbolizing legitimate divine sanction.

questions.question: True or False: Jehoiada’s actions in 2 Chronicles 23 demonstrate a deliberate restoration of the Davidic covenant and temple worship against a backdrop of idolatry and illegitimate rule.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The chapter shows Jehoiada restoring temple worship, crowning the legitimate Davidic heir, and destroying Baal worship, fulfilling the Davidic covenant (2 Chronicles 23:3,16-18).

questions.question: What literary device is prominently displayed in the arrangement of the Levites around the king with weapons, as described in 2 Chronicles 23:7 and 10?
options: Chiasm emphasizing protection and covenant loyalty
Allegory representing the battle between good and evil
Parable illustrating faithfulness
Hyperbole to exaggerate the king's power
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm emphasizing protection and covenant loyalty
questions.explanation: The strategic positioning of armed Levites around the king forms a chiastic structure highlighting protection and loyalty to the Davidic covenant (verses 7 and 10).

questions.question: In the cultural context of ancient Judah, what does the tearing of clothes by Athaliah signify in 2 Chronicles 23:13?
options: An expression of grief or shock, often signaling mourning or outrage
A ritual of blessing the king
A sign of surrender to the new king
A customary greeting among leaders
questions.correctAnswer: An expression of grief or shock, often signaling mourning or outrage
questions.explanation: Tearing clothes was a common Near Eastern gesture of lamentation or protest, here expressing Athaliah's outrage at the coronation (verse 13).

theological.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 23 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Chronicles Chapter 23 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who did Jehoiada take into covenant with him to strengthen himself in the seventh year?
options: Captains of hundreds including Azariah, Ishmael, and others
The priests and Levites only
The prophets and elders of Judah
Foreign allies from surrounding nations
questions.correctAnswer: Captains of hundreds including Azariah, Ishmael, and others
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:1 describes Jehoiada strengthening himself by taking captains of hundreds, naming Azariah the son of Jeroham, Ishmael the son of Jehohanan, and others into covenant. This demonstrates God's providential preparation and human agency in securing the Davidic line (cf. 1 Samuel 10:26; 2 Kings 11:4; Psalm 18:34; Hebrews 11:34).

questions.question: What was the purpose of gathering the Levites and chief fathers of Israel to Jerusalem?
options: To make a covenant with the king in the house of God
To plan a military attack against enemies
To offer sacrifices to Baal
To establish a new temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: To make a covenant with the king in the house of God
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:2-3 explains that Levites and the chief fathers came to Jerusalem, where the congregation made a covenant with the king in the house of God. This highlights the covenantal nature of kingship under God’s authority (cf. Exodus 24:3-8; Deuteronomy 17:14-20; Psalm 89:3-4; Luke 1:32).

questions.question: According to Jehoiada's instructions, what portion of priests and Levites served as porters of the doors on the sabbath?
options: A third part
Half
Two thirds
All of them
questions.correctAnswer: A third part
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:4 states that a third part of the priests and Levites entering on the sabbath were to serve as porters of the doors. This division of labor reflects the order and holiness required in temple service (cf. Numbers 3:6-9; 1 Chronicles 9:22; Ezekiel 44:2-3; Hebrews 9:6).

questions.question: What was the primary restriction given concerning who could enter the house of the LORD?
options: Only priests and those ministering of the Levites
All the people of Judah
The king and his nobles
Anyone who wished to enter
questions.correctAnswer: Only priests and those ministering of the Levites
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:6 commands that no one but the priests and Levites who minister are to enter the house of the LORD because they are holy. This emphasizes God's holiness and the sanctity of worship spaces (cf. Exodus 19:6; Leviticus 10:1-3; Hebrews 7:26-27; 1 Peter 1:15-16).

questions.question: What were the Levites instructed to do to protect the king when he came into the house of the LORD?
options: Compass him round about with weapons in hand, putting to death anyone else who entered
Stand silently and pray
Close the doors and keep watch outside
Sing praises to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Compass him round about with weapons in hand, putting to death anyone else who entered
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:7 requires the Levites to surround the king with weapons and to kill anyone else who comes into the house, underscoring the seriousness of safeguarding the anointed king and God's covenantal order (cf. 1 Samuel 26:9-11; Psalm 18:34; 2 Kings 11:5-6; Revelation 19:11).

questions.question: What weapons did Jehoiada the priest deliver to the captains of hundreds?
options: Spears, bucklers, and shields from King David's store
Swords and bows made by the Levites
Newly forged iron weapons
Only wooden staffs for defense
questions.correctAnswer: Spears, bucklers, and shields from King David's store
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:9 notes that Jehoiada gave the captains spears, bucklers, and shields that had belonged to King David, symbolizing continuity of divine authority and protection through God's anointed line (cf. 1 Samuel 17:45; Psalm 18:34; Ephesians 6:13-17; Hebrews 11:34).

questions.question: What was proclaimed over the king's son when he was made king by Jehoiada and the people?
options: God save the king
Long live the kingdom
Blessed be the ruler
Peace and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: God save the king
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:11 records that after putting the crown on the king's son and anointing him, Jehoiada and his sons declared, 'God save the king,' acknowledging God's sovereign rule through the Davidic king (cf. Psalm 20:9; 1 Samuel 10:24; Romans 13:1; Revelation 19:16).

questions.question: How did Athaliah react when she saw the king standing at his pillar with the princes and trumpets?
options: She rent her clothes and cried 'Treason, Treason'
She praised God for the king's coronation
She fled the temple quietly
She called for a feast to celebrate
questions.correctAnswer: She rent her clothes and cried 'Treason, Treason'
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:13 shows Athaliah's dramatic reaction of tearing her clothes and shouting 'Treason,' revealing her opposition to God's anointed and her rejection of His covenant plan (cf. 2 Kings 11:14; Ezekiel 36:26-27; Matthew 27:24; Acts 4:26).

questions.question: What command did Jehoiada give regarding Athaliah after bringing out the captains of hundreds?
options: Have her brought out of the ranges and slain if anyone followed her
Let her remain in the temple under guard
Send her into exile peacefully
Allow her to appeal before the people
questions.correctAnswer: Have her brought out of the ranges and slain if anyone followed her
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:14 states Jehoiada's command to remove Athaliah from the temple precincts and that anyone who followed her should be slain, but not to kill her in the house of the LORD, emphasizing respect for sacred space even amid judgment (cf. Exodus 22:28; 1 Samuel 19:11-12; Hebrews 12:29; Revelation 6:10).

questions.question: Where was Athaliah slain after being taken from the house of the LORD?
options: At the entering of the horse gate by the king's house
In the temple courtyard
On the mount of Olives
At the city gate of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: At the entering of the horse gate by the king's house
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:15 indicates Athaliah was slain at the horse gate near the king's house, showing the fulfillment of divine justice outside the sacred precincts (cf. 2 Kings 11:16; Ezekiel 21:3-5; Revelation 19:11-21; Romans 13:4).

questions.question: What covenant did Jehoiada make between himself, the people, and the king?
options: That they would be the LORD’s people
That they would rebuild the temple
That they would serve Baal no more
That they would conquer surrounding nations
questions.correctAnswer: That they would be the LORD’s people
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:16 records a covenant to be the LORD's people, reflecting a renewed commitment to God's exclusive lordship and covenant faithfulness (cf. Exodus 19:5; Deuteronomy 7:6; Jeremiah 31:33; 1 Corinthians 6:19-20; Revelation 21:3-4).

questions.question: What did the people do to the house of Baal after the covenant was made?
options: They broke it down and slew Mattan the priest of Baal
They repaired it and resumed worship
They ignored it and left it standing
They consecrated it to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They broke it down and slew Mattan the priest of Baal
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:17 shows the people destroyed the house of Baal and killed its priest, demonstrating God's demand for purity and the rejection of idolatry (cf. Exodus 20:3-5; Deuteronomy 12:2-3; 1 Kings 18:40; Galatians 5:19-21; 1 John 5:21).

questions.question: How did Jehoiada organize the service in the house of the LORD following the covenant?
options: By appointing priests and Levites to offer offerings with rejoicing and singing
By instituting silent worship only
By delegating worship to foreign priests
By abolishing burnt offerings
questions.correctAnswer: By appointing priests and Levites to offer offerings with rejoicing and singing
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:18 describes Jehoiada appointing priests and Levites to offer burnt offerings with rejoicing and singing, in accordance with the Mosaic law and David’s ordinances, emphasizing orderly worship and praise (cf. Leviticus 1:3-4; Psalm 100:1-2; Colossians 3:16; Hebrews 13:15).

questions.question: What was the role of the porters that Jehoiada set at the gates of the house of the LORD?
options: To prevent anyone unclean from entering
To welcome foreigners into the temple
To collect offerings from the people
To sing praises during worship
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent anyone unclean from entering
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:19 states the porters were appointed to ensure no one unclean entered the temple, protecting the holiness of God's dwelling place (cf. Leviticus 21:1-3; Ezekiel 44:9; 1 Timothy 3:15; Revelation 21:27).

questions.question: How was the king brought from the house of the LORD to the throne of the kingdom?
options: Through the high gate into the king's house by captains, nobles, governors, and people
By a private path unknown to others
On a chariot through the city streets
Carried by priests alone
questions.correctAnswer: Through the high gate into the king's house by captains, nobles, governors, and people
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 23:20 explains that captains, nobles, governors, and all the people led the king from the house of the LORD through the high gate to the king’s house, symbolizing public affirmation of God’s chosen king (cf. 1 Kings 1:39; Psalm 72:11; John 12:13; Revelation 7:9).
